trans-unit.target: Test with the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile

trans-unit.source: Simulate real-world interaction with a device and test the features of your app by using the tools included with Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile.
trans-unit.target: Simulate real-world interaction with a device and test the features of your app by using the tools included with Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile.

trans-unit.source: Test with the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile
trans-unit.target: Test with the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile

trans-unit.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132)
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132)

trans-unit.source: Simulate real-world interaction with a device and test the features of your app by using the tools included with Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile.
trans-unit.target: Simulate real-world interaction with a device and test the features of your app by using the tools included with Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile.

trans-unit.source: The emulator is a desktop application that emulates a mobile device running Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: The emulator is a desktop application that emulates a mobile device running Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: It provides a virtualized environment in which you can debug and test Windows apps without a physical device.
trans-unit.target: It provides a virtualized environment in which you can debug and test Windows apps without a physical device.

trans-unit.source: It also provides an isolated environment for your application prototypes.
trans-unit.target: It also provides an isolated environment for your application prototypes.

trans-unit.source: The emulator is designed to provide comparable performance to an actual device.
trans-unit.target: The emulator is designed to provide comparable performance to an actual device.

trans-unit.source: Before you publish your app to the Windows Store, however, we recommend that you test your app on a physical device.
trans-unit.target: Before you publish your app to the Windows Store, however, we recommend that you test your app on a physical device.

trans-unit.source: You can test your universal app using a unique Windows 10 Mobile emulator image for various screen resolution and screen size configurations.
trans-unit.target: You can test your universal app using a unique Windows 10 Mobile emulator image for various screen resolution and screen size configurations.

trans-unit.source: You can simulate real-world interaction with a device and test various features of your app by using the tools included in the Microsoft Emulator.
trans-unit.target: You can simulate real-world interaction with a device and test various features of your app by using the tools included in the Microsoft Emulator.

trans-unit.source: System requirements
trans-unit.target: System requirements

trans-unit.source: Your computer must meet the following requirements:
trans-unit.target: Your computer must meet the following requirements:

trans-unit.source: BIOS
trans-unit.target: BIOS

trans-unit.source: Hardware-assisted virtualization.
trans-unit.target: Hardware-assisted virtualization.

trans-unit.source: Second Level Address Translation (SLAT).
trans-unit.target: Second Level Address Translation (SLAT).

trans-unit.source: Hardware-based Data Execution Prevention (DEP).
trans-unit.target: Hardware-based Data Execution Prevention (DEP).

trans-unit.source: RAM
trans-unit.target: RAM

trans-unit.source: 4 GB or more.
trans-unit.target: 4 GB or more.

trans-unit.source: Operating system
trans-unit.target: Operating system

trans-unit.source: Windows 8 or higher (Windows 10 strongly recommended)
trans-unit.target: Windows 8 or higher (Windows 10 strongly recommended)

trans-unit.source: 64-bit
trans-unit.target: 64-bit

trans-unit.source: Pro edition or higher
trans-unit.target: Pro edition or higher

trans-unit.source: To check the BIOS requirements, see [How to enable Hyper-V for the emulator for Windows Phone 8](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/xaml/jj863509.aspx).
trans-unit.target: To check the BIOS requirements, see [How to enable Hyper-V for the emulator for Windows Phone 8](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/xaml/jj863509.aspx).

trans-unit.source: To check requirements for RAM and operating system, in Control Panel, click **System and Security**, and then click **System**.
trans-unit.target: To check requirements for RAM and operating system, in Control Panel, click **System and Security**, and then click **System**.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile requires Visual Studio 2015; it is not backward compatible with earlier versions of Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile requires Visual Studio 2015; it is not backward compatible with earlier versions of Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile cannot load apps that target the Windows Phone OS version earlier than Windows Phone OS 7.1.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile cannot load apps that target the Windows Phone OS version earlier than Windows Phone OS 7.1.

trans-unit.source: Installing and uninstalling
trans-unit.target: Installing and uninstalling

trans-unit.source: **Installing**.
trans-unit.target: **Installing**.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile ships as part of the Windows 10 SDK.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile ships as part of the Windows 10 SDK.

trans-unit.source: The Windows 10 SDK and emulator can be installed as part of the Visual Studio 2015 install.
trans-unit.target: The Windows 10 SDK and emulator can be installed as part of the Visual Studio 2015 install.

trans-unit.source: See the [Visual Studio download page](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=534785).
trans-unit.target: See the [Visual Studio download page](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=534785).

trans-unit.source: You can also install the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile using the Microsoft Emulator setup.
trans-unit.target: You can also install the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile using the Microsoft Emulator setup.

trans-unit.source: See the [Windows 10 Tools download page](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=534189).
trans-unit.target: See the [Windows 10 Tools download page](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=534189).

trans-unit.source: **Uninstalling**.
trans-unit.target: **Uninstalling**.

trans-unit.source: You can uninstall the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile using Visual Studio setup/repair.
trans-unit.target: You can uninstall the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile using Visual Studio setup/repair.

trans-unit.source: Or you can use **Programs and Features** under **Control Panel** to remove the emulator.
trans-unit.target: Or you can use **Programs and Features** under **Control Panel** to remove the emulator.

trans-unit.source: When you uninstall the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile, the Hyper-V Virtual Ethernet Adapter that was created for the emulator to use is not automatically removed.
trans-unit.target: When you uninstall the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile, the Hyper-V Virtual Ethernet Adapter that was created for the emulator to use is not automatically removed.

trans-unit.source: You can manually remove this virtual adapter from **Network Connections** in **Control Panel**.
trans-unit.target: You can manually remove this virtual adapter from **Network Connections** in **Control Panel**.

trans-unit.source: What’s new in Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile
trans-unit.target: What’s new in Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile

trans-unit.source: In addition to providing support for Universal Windows Platform (UWP), the emulator has added the following functionality:
trans-unit.target: In addition to providing support for Universal Windows Platform (UWP), the emulator has added the following functionality:

trans-unit.source: Mouse input mode support to differentiate between mouse and single touch input.
trans-unit.target: Mouse input mode support to differentiate between mouse and single touch input.

trans-unit.source: NFC Support.
trans-unit.target: NFC Support.

trans-unit.source: The emulator allows you to simulate NFC and make it possible to test and develop NFC/Proximity-enabled universal apps.
trans-unit.target: The emulator allows you to simulate NFC and make it possible to test and develop NFC/Proximity-enabled universal apps.

trans-unit.source: Native hardware acceleration improves graphics performance in the emulator by using the local graphics card.
trans-unit.target: Native hardware acceleration improves graphics performance in the emulator by using the local graphics card.

trans-unit.source: You must have a supported graphics card installed, and enable acceleration on the **Sensors** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools** settings user interface in order to use acceleration.
trans-unit.target: You must have a supported graphics card installed, and enable acceleration on the **Sensors** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools** settings user interface in order to use acceleration.

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: One important user interface change has been made.
trans-unit.target: One important user interface change has been made.

trans-unit.source: In this version of the emulator, the keyboard shortcut to show or hide the hardware keyboard is now F4, acting as a toggle, rather than the Page Up/Page Down pair of keys used in earlier emulators.
trans-unit.target: In this version of the emulator, the keyboard shortcut to show or hide the hardware keyboard is now F4, acting as a toggle, rather than the Page Up/Page Down pair of keys used in earlier emulators.

trans-unit.source: Features that you can test in the emulator
trans-unit.target: Features that you can test in the emulator

trans-unit.source: In addition to the new features mentioned in the previous section, you can test the following commonly used features in the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the new features mentioned in the previous section, you can test the following commonly used features in the Microsoft Emulator for Windows 10 Mobile.

trans-unit.source: **Screen resolution, screen size, and memory**.
trans-unit.target: **Screen resolution, screen size, and memory**.

trans-unit.source: Reach a broad market for your app by testing it on various emulator images to simulate various screen resolutions, physical sizes, and memory constraints.
trans-unit.target: Reach a broad market for your app by testing it on various emulator images to simulate various screen resolutions, physical sizes, and memory constraints.

trans-unit.source: Available emulators with resolution, size, and memory
trans-unit.target: Available emulators with resolution, size, and memory

trans-unit.source: **Screen configuration**.
trans-unit.target: **Screen configuration**.

trans-unit.source: Change the emulator from portrait to landscape mode.
trans-unit.target: Change the emulator from portrait to landscape mode.

trans-unit.source: Change the zoom setting to fit the emulator to your desktop screen.
trans-unit.target: Change the zoom setting to fit the emulator to your desktop screen.

trans-unit.source: **Networking**.
trans-unit.target: **Networking**.

trans-unit.source: Networking support is integrated with Windows Phone Emulator.
trans-unit.target: Networking support is integrated with Windows Phone Emulator.

trans-unit.source: Networking is enabled by default.
trans-unit.target: Networking is enabled by default.

trans-unit.source: You do not have to install network drivers for Windows Phone Emulator or configure networking options manually in most environments.
trans-unit.target: You do not have to install network drivers for Windows Phone Emulator or configure networking options manually in most environments.

trans-unit.source: The emulator uses the network connection of the host computer.
trans-unit.target: The emulator uses the network connection of the host computer.

trans-unit.source: It does not appear as a separate device on the network.
trans-unit.target: It does not appear as a separate device on the network.

trans-unit.source: This eliminates some of the configuration issues that users encountered with the Windows Phone SDK 8.0 emulator.
trans-unit.target: This eliminates some of the configuration issues that users encountered with the Windows Phone SDK 8.0 emulator.

trans-unit.source: **Language and region settings**.
trans-unit.target: **Language and region settings**.

trans-unit.source: Prepare your app for an international market by changing the display language and region settings in Windows Phone Emulator.
trans-unit.target: Prepare your app for an international market by changing the display language and region settings in Windows Phone Emulator.

trans-unit.source: On the running emulator, go to the **Settings** app, then select the **system** settings, then select **language** or **region**.
trans-unit.target: On the running emulator, go to the **Settings** app, then select the **system** settings, then select **language** or **region**.

trans-unit.source: Change the settings that you want to test.
trans-unit.target: Change the settings that you want to test.

trans-unit.source: If you're prompted, click **restart phone** to apply the new settings and restart the emulator.
trans-unit.target: If you're prompted, click **restart phone** to apply the new settings and restart the emulator.

trans-unit.source: **Application lifecycle and tombstoning**.
trans-unit.target: **Application lifecycle and tombstoning**.

trans-unit.source: Test the behavior or your app when it's deactivated or tombstoned by changing the value of the option **Tombstone upon deactivation while debugging** on the **Debug** page of project properties.
trans-unit.target: Test the behavior or your app when it's deactivated or tombstoned by changing the value of the option **Tombstone upon deactivation while debugging** on the **Debug** page of project properties.

trans-unit.source: **Local folder storage (previously known as isolated storage)**.
trans-unit.target: **Local folder storage (previously known as isolated storage)**.

trans-unit.source: Data in isolated storage persists while the emulator is running, but is lost once the emulator closes.
trans-unit.target: Data in isolated storage persists while the emulator is running, but is lost once the emulator closes.

trans-unit.source: **Microphone**.
trans-unit.target: **Microphone**.

trans-unit.source: Requires and uses the microphone on the host computer.
trans-unit.target: Requires and uses the microphone on the host computer.

trans-unit.source: **Lock screen**.
trans-unit.target: **Lock screen**.

trans-unit.source: With the emulator open, press F12 on your computer keyboard twice.
trans-unit.target: With the emulator open, press F12 on your computer keyboard twice.

trans-unit.source: The F12 key emulates the power button on the phone.
trans-unit.target: The F12 key emulates the power button on the phone.

trans-unit.source: The first key press turns off the display.
trans-unit.target: The first key press turns off the display.

trans-unit.source: The second key press turns the display on again with the lock screen engaged.
trans-unit.target: The second key press turns the display on again with the lock screen engaged.

trans-unit.source: Unlock the screen by using the mouse to slide the lock screen upward.
trans-unit.target: Unlock the screen by using the mouse to slide the lock screen upward.

trans-unit.source: Features that you can't test in the emulator
trans-unit.target: Features that you can't test in the emulator

trans-unit.source: Test the following features only on a physical device.
trans-unit.target: Test the following features only on a physical device.

trans-unit.source: Compass
trans-unit.target: Compass

trans-unit.source: Gyroscope
trans-unit.target: Gyroscope

trans-unit.source: Vibration controller
trans-unit.target: Vibration controller

trans-unit.source: Brightness.
trans-unit.target: Brightness.

trans-unit.source: The brightness level of the emulator is always High.
trans-unit.target: The brightness level of the emulator is always High.

trans-unit.source: High-resolution video.
trans-unit.target: High-resolution video.

trans-unit.source: Videos with a resolution higher than VGA resolution (640 x 480) cannot be displayed reliably, especially on emulator images with only 512MB of memory.
trans-unit.target: Videos with a resolution higher than VGA resolution (640 x 480) cannot be displayed reliably, especially on emulator images with only 512MB of memory.

trans-unit.source: Mouse input
trans-unit.target: Mouse input

trans-unit.source: Simulate mouse input using the physical mouse or trackpad on your Windows PC and the mouse input button on the emulator toolbar.
trans-unit.target: Simulate mouse input using the physical mouse or trackpad on your Windows PC and the mouse input button on the emulator toolbar.

trans-unit.source: This feature is useful if your app provides the user with an ability to utilize a mouse paired to their Windows 10 device to provide input.
trans-unit.target: This feature is useful if your app provides the user with an ability to utilize a mouse paired to their Windows 10 device to provide input.

trans-unit.source: Tap the mouse input button on the emulator toolbar to enable mouse input.
trans-unit.target: Tap the mouse input button on the emulator toolbar to enable mouse input.

trans-unit.source: Any click events within the emulator chrome will now be sent to the Windows 10 Mobile OS running inside the emulator VM as mouse events.
trans-unit.target: Any click events within the emulator chrome will now be sent to the Windows 10 Mobile OS running inside the emulator VM as mouse events.

trans-unit.source: Emulator screen with mouse input enabled
trans-unit.target: Emulator screen with mouse input enabled

trans-unit.source: The emulator screen with the mouse input enabled.
trans-unit.target: The emulator screen with the mouse input enabled.

trans-unit.source: The mouse input button on the emulator toolbar
trans-unit.target: The mouse input button on the emulator toolbar

trans-unit.source: The mouse input button on the emulator toolbar.
trans-unit.target: The mouse input button on the emulator toolbar.

trans-unit.source: Near Field Communications (NFC)
trans-unit.target: Near Field Communications (NFC)

trans-unit.source: Build and test apps that use Near Field Communication (NFC) enabled features on Windows 10 Mobile by using the **NFC** tab of the emulator’s **Additional Tools** menu.
trans-unit.target: Build and test apps that use Near Field Communication (NFC) enabled features on Windows 10 Mobile by using the **NFC** tab of the emulator’s **Additional Tools** menu.

trans-unit.source: NFC is useful for a number of scenarios ranging from Proximity scenarios (such as tap to share) to card emulation (such as tap to pay).
trans-unit.target: NFC is useful for a number of scenarios ranging from Proximity scenarios (such as tap to share) to card emulation (such as tap to pay).

trans-unit.source: You can test your app by simulating a pair of phones tapping together by using a pair of emulators, or you can test your app by simulating a tap to a tag.
trans-unit.target: You can test your app by simulating a pair of phones tapping together by using a pair of emulators, or you can test your app by simulating a tap to a tag.

trans-unit.source: Also in Windows 10, mobile devices are enabled with HCE (Host Card Emulation) feature and by using the phone emulator you can simulate tapping your device to a payment terminal for APDU command-response traffic.
trans-unit.target: Also in Windows 10, mobile devices are enabled with HCE (Host Card Emulation) feature and by using the phone emulator you can simulate tapping your device to a payment terminal for APDU command-response traffic.

trans-unit.source: The NFC tab supports three modes:
trans-unit.target: The NFC tab supports three modes:

trans-unit.source: Proximity Mode
trans-unit.target: Proximity Mode

trans-unit.source: HCE (Host Card Emulation) Mode
trans-unit.target: HCE (Host Card Emulation) Mode

trans-unit.source: Smart Card Reader Mode
trans-unit.target: Smart Card Reader Mode

trans-unit.source: In all modes, the emulator window has three areas of interest.
trans-unit.target: In all modes, the emulator window has three areas of interest.

trans-unit.source: The top left section is specific to the mode selected.
trans-unit.target: The top left section is specific to the mode selected.

trans-unit.source: The features of this section depend on the mode, and are detailed in the mode-specific sections below.
trans-unit.target: The features of this section depend on the mode, and are detailed in the mode-specific sections below.

trans-unit.source: The top right section lists the logs.
trans-unit.target: The top right section lists the logs.

trans-unit.source: When you tap a pair of devices together (or tap to the POS terminal) the tap event is logged and when the devices are untapped the untap event is logged.
trans-unit.target: When you tap a pair of devices together (or tap to the POS terminal) the tap event is logged and when the devices are untapped the untap event is logged.

trans-unit.source: This section also records if your app responded before the connection is broken or any other action you have taken in the emulator UI with time stamps.
trans-unit.target: This section also records if your app responded before the connection is broken or any other action you have taken in the emulator UI with time stamps.

trans-unit.source: Logs are persistent between mode switches, and you can clear the logs at any point by hitting the **Clear** button above the **Logs** screen.
trans-unit.target: Logs are persistent between mode switches, and you can clear the logs at any point by hitting the **Clear** button above the **Logs** screen.

trans-unit.source: The bottom half of the screen is the message log and shows the transcript of all messages sent or received over the currently selected connection, depending on the mode selected.
trans-unit.target: The bottom half of the screen is the message log and shows the transcript of all messages sent or received over the currently selected connection, depending on the mode selected.

trans-unit.source: **Important** When you first launch the tapper tool, you will get a Windows Firewall prompt.
trans-unit.target: **Important** When you first launch the tapper tool, you will get a Windows Firewall prompt.

trans-unit.source: You MUST select ALL 3 check boxes and allow the tool through the firewall, or the tool will silently fail to work.
trans-unit.target: You MUST select ALL 3 check boxes and allow the tool through the firewall, or the tool will silently fail to work.

trans-unit.source: After launching the quick start installer, make sure you follow the above instruction to select all 3 check boxes on the firewall prompt.
trans-unit.target: After launching the quick start installer, make sure you follow the above instruction to select all 3 check boxes on the firewall prompt.

trans-unit.source: Also, the tapper tool must be installed and used on the same physical host machine as the Microsoft Emulator.
trans-unit.target: Also, the tapper tool must be installed and used on the same physical host machine as the Microsoft Emulator.

trans-unit.source: Proximity mode
trans-unit.target: Proximity mode

trans-unit.source: To simulate a pair of phones tapping together you'll need to launch a pair of Windows Phone 8 emulators.
trans-unit.target: To simulate a pair of phones tapping together you'll need to launch a pair of Windows Phone 8 emulators.

trans-unit.source: Since Visual Studio doesn't support running two identical emulators at the same time, you'll need to select different resolutions for each of the emulators to work around it.
trans-unit.target: Since Visual Studio doesn't support running two identical emulators at the same time, you'll need to select different resolutions for each of the emulators to work around it.

trans-unit.source: The NFC Proximity page
trans-unit.target: The NFC Proximity page

trans-unit.source: When you check the **Enable discovery of peer devices** checkbox, the **Peer device** dropdown box shows Microsoft Emulators (running on the same physical host machine or in the local network) as well as the Windows machines running the simulator driver (running on the same machine or in the local network).
trans-unit.target: When you check the **Enable discovery of peer devices** checkbox, the **Peer device** dropdown box shows Microsoft Emulators (running on the same physical host machine or in the local network) as well as the Windows machines running the simulator driver (running on the same machine or in the local network).

trans-unit.source: Once both emulators are running:
trans-unit.target: Once both emulators are running:

trans-unit.source: Select the emulator you would like to target in the **Peer device** list.
trans-unit.target: Select the emulator you would like to target in the **Peer device** list.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Send to peer device** radio button.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Send to peer device** radio button.

trans-unit.source: Click **Tap** button.
trans-unit.target: Click **Tap** button.

trans-unit.source: This will simulate the two devices tapping together and you should be hearing the NFC tap notification sound
trans-unit.target: This will simulate the two devices tapping together and you should be hearing the NFC tap notification sound

trans-unit.source: To disconnect the 2 devices, simply hit the **Untap** button.
trans-unit.target: To disconnect the 2 devices, simply hit the **Untap** button.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can enable **Automatically untap in (seconds)** check box where you can specify the number of seconds you want the devices to be tapped and they will be automatically untapped after the specified number of seconds (simulating what would be expected of a user in real life, they would only hold their phones together for a short time).
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can enable **Automatically untap in (seconds)** check box where you can specify the number of seconds you want the devices to be tapped and they will be automatically untapped after the specified number of seconds (simulating what would be expected of a user in real life, they would only hold their phones together for a short time).

trans-unit.source: Note however that currently the message log isn't available after the connection has been untapped.
trans-unit.target: Note however that currently the message log isn't available after the connection has been untapped.

trans-unit.source: To simulate reading messages from a tag or receiving messages from another device:
trans-unit.target: To simulate reading messages from a tag or receiving messages from another device:

trans-unit.source: Select the **Send to self** radio button to test scenarios that require only one NFC enabled device.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Send to self** radio button to test scenarios that require only one NFC enabled device.

trans-unit.source: Click **Tap** button.
trans-unit.target: Click **Tap** button.

trans-unit.source: This will simulate the tapping a device to a tag and you should be hearing the NFC tap notification sound
trans-unit.target: This will simulate the tapping a device to a tag and you should be hearing the NFC tap notification sound

trans-unit.source: To disconnect, simply hit the **Untap** button.
trans-unit.target: To disconnect, simply hit the **Untap** button.

trans-unit.source: Using the proximity mode you can inject messages as if they came from a tag or another peer device.
trans-unit.target: Using the proximity mode you can inject messages as if they came from a tag or another peer device.

trans-unit.source: The toolallows you to send messages of the following types.
trans-unit.target: The toolallows you to send messages of the following types.

trans-unit.source: WindowsURI
trans-unit.target: WindowsURI

trans-unit.source: WindowsMime
trans-unit.target: WindowsMime

trans-unit.source: WritableTag
trans-unit.target: WritableTag

trans-unit.source: Pairing:Bluetooth
trans-unit.target: Pairing:Bluetooth

trans-unit.source: NDEF
trans-unit.target: NDEF

trans-unit.source: NDEF:MIME
trans-unit.target: NDEF:MIME

trans-unit.source: NDEF:URI
trans-unit.target: NDEF:URI

trans-unit.source: NDEF:wkt.U
trans-unit.target: NDEF:wkt.U

trans-unit.source: You can either create these messages by editing the **Payload** windows or providing them in a file.
trans-unit.target: You can either create these messages by editing the **Payload** windows or providing them in a file.

trans-unit.source: For more information about these types and how to use them please refer to the Remarks section of the[**ProximityDevice.PublishBinaryMessage**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh701129) reference page.
trans-unit.target: For more information about these types and how to use them please refer to the Remarks section of the[**ProximityDevice.PublishBinaryMessage**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh701129) reference page.

trans-unit.source: The Windows 8 Driver Kit (WDK) includes a driver sample that exposes the same protocol as the Windows Phone 8 emulator.
trans-unit.target: The Windows 8 Driver Kit (WDK) includes a driver sample that exposes the same protocol as the Windows Phone 8 emulator.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to download the DDK, build that sample driver, install it on a Windows 8 device, then add the Windows 8 device's IP address or hostname to the devices list and tap it either with another Windows 8 device or with a Windows Phone 8 emulator.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to download the DDK, build that sample driver, install it on a Windows 8 device, then add the Windows 8 device's IP address or hostname to the devices list and tap it either with another Windows 8 device or with a Windows Phone 8 emulator.

trans-unit.source: Host Card Emulation (HCE) Mode
trans-unit.target: Host Card Emulation (HCE) Mode

trans-unit.source: In Host Card Emulation (HCE) mode you can test your HCE-based card emulation application by writing your own custom scripts to simulate a smart card reader terminal, such as a Point of Sale (POS) terminal.
trans-unit.target: In Host Card Emulation (HCE) mode you can test your HCE-based card emulation application by writing your own custom scripts to simulate a smart card reader terminal, such as a Point of Sale (POS) terminal.

trans-unit.source: This tool assumes that you are familiar with the command response pairs (compliant with ISO-7816-4) that are sent between a reader terminal (such as POS, badge reader or transit card reader) and the smart card (that you are emulating in your application).
trans-unit.target: This tool assumes that you are familiar with the command response pairs (compliant with ISO-7816-4) that are sent between a reader terminal (such as POS, badge reader or transit card reader) and the smart card (that you are emulating in your application).

trans-unit.source: The NFC HCE page
trans-unit.target: The NFC HCE page

trans-unit.source: Create a new script by clicking the **Add** button in the script editor section.
trans-unit.target: Create a new script by clicking the **Add** button in the script editor section.

trans-unit.source: You can provide a name for your script and after you are done with editing, you can save your script using the **Save** button.
trans-unit.target: You can provide a name for your script and after you are done with editing, you can save your script using the **Save** button.

trans-unit.source: Your saved scripts will be available the next time you launch the emulator.
trans-unit.target: Your saved scripts will be available the next time you launch the emulator.

trans-unit.source: Run your scripts by hitting the **Play** button in the scripts editor window.
trans-unit.target: Run your scripts by hitting the **Play** button in the scripts editor window.

trans-unit.source: This action results in simulating of tapping your phone to the terminal and sending commands written in your script.
trans-unit.target: This action results in simulating of tapping your phone to the terminal and sending commands written in your script.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively you can hit the **Tap** button and then the **Play** button, until you hit **Play** the script will not run.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively you can hit the **Tap** button and then the **Play** button, until you hit **Play** the script will not run.

trans-unit.source: Stop sending commands by hitting the **Stop** button, which stops sending the commands to your application but the devices remain tapped until you hit the **Untap** button.
trans-unit.target: Stop sending commands by hitting the **Stop** button, which stops sending the commands to your application but the devices remain tapped until you hit the **Untap** button.

trans-unit.source: Delete your scripts by selecting the script in the dropdown menu and hitting **Delete** button.
trans-unit.target: Delete your scripts by selecting the script in the dropdown menu and hitting **Delete** button.

trans-unit.source: The emulator tool does not check for the syntax of your scripts until you run the script using the **Play** button.
trans-unit.target: The emulator tool does not check for the syntax of your scripts until you run the script using the **Play** button.

trans-unit.source: The messages sent by your script are dependent on your implementation of your card emulation app.
trans-unit.target: The messages sent by your script are dependent on your implementation of your card emulation app.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the terminal simulator tool from MasterCard ([https://www.terminalsimulator.com/](https://www.terminalsimulator.com/ )) for payments app testing.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the terminal simulator tool from MasterCard ([https://www.terminalsimulator.com/](https://www.terminalsimulator.com/ )) for payments app testing.

trans-unit.source: Check the **Enable MasterCard** listener checkbox below the script editor windows and launch the simulator from MasterCard.
trans-unit.target: Check the **Enable MasterCard** listener checkbox below the script editor windows and launch the simulator from MasterCard.

trans-unit.source: Using the tool, you can generate commands that are relayed to your application running on the emulator through the NFC tool.
trans-unit.target: Using the tool, you can generate commands that are relayed to your application running on the emulator through the NFC tool.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about HCE support and how to develop HCE apps in Windows 10 Mobile, please refer to the [Microsoft NFC Team Blog](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=534749).
trans-unit.target: To learn more about HCE support and how to develop HCE apps in Windows 10 Mobile, please refer to the [Microsoft NFC Team Blog](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=534749).

trans-unit.source: How to Create Scripts for HCE Testing
trans-unit.target: How to Create Scripts for HCE Testing

trans-unit.source: The scripts are written as C# code and your script’s Run method is called when you click the **Play** button, this method takes an IScriptProcessor interface which is used to transceive APDU commands, output to the log window, and control the timeout for waiting on an APDU response from the phone.
trans-unit.target: The scripts are written as C# code and your script’s Run method is called when you click the **Play** button, this method takes an IScriptProcessor interface which is used to transceive APDU commands, output to the log window, and control the timeout for waiting on an APDU response from the phone.

trans-unit.source: Below is a reference on what functionality is available:
trans-unit.target: Below is a reference on what functionality is available:

trans-unit.source: Smart Card Reader Mode
trans-unit.target: Smart Card Reader Mode

trans-unit.source: The emulator can be connected to a smart card reader device on your host computer, such that smart cards inserted or tapped will show up to your phone application and can be communicated to with APDUs using the [**Windows.Devices.SmartCards.SmartCardConnection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Dn608002) class.
trans-unit.target: The emulator can be connected to a smart card reader device on your host computer, such that smart cards inserted or tapped will show up to your phone application and can be communicated to with APDUs using the [**Windows.Devices.SmartCards.SmartCardConnection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Dn608002) class.

trans-unit.source: For this to work, you will need a compatible smart card reader device attached to your computer, USB smart card readers (both NFC/contactless and insert/contact) are widely available.
trans-unit.target: For this to work, you will need a compatible smart card reader device attached to your computer, USB smart card readers (both NFC/contactless and insert/contact) are widely available.

trans-unit.source: To enable the emulator to work with an attached smart card reader, first choose the **Card Reader** mode which should show a dropdown box listing all the compatible smart card readers attached to the host system, then choose the smart card reader device you’d like to be connected from the dropdown.
trans-unit.target: To enable the emulator to work with an attached smart card reader, first choose the **Card Reader** mode which should show a dropdown box listing all the compatible smart card readers attached to the host system, then choose the smart card reader device you’d like to be connected from the dropdown.

trans-unit.source: Note that not all NFC-capable smart card readers support some types of NFC cards, and some do not support the standard PC/SC storage card APDU commands.
trans-unit.target: Note that not all NFC-capable smart card readers support some types of NFC cards, and some do not support the standard PC/SC storage card APDU commands.

trans-unit.source: Multi-point input
trans-unit.target: Multi-point input

trans-unit.source: Simulate multi-touch input for pinching and zooming, rotating, and panning objects by using the **Multi-touch Input** button on the emulator toolbar.
trans-unit.target: Simulate multi-touch input for pinching and zooming, rotating, and panning objects by using the **Multi-touch Input** button on the emulator toolbar.

trans-unit.source: This feature is useful if your app displays photos, maps, or other visual elements that users can pinch and zoom, rotate, or pan.
trans-unit.target: This feature is useful if your app displays photos, maps, or other visual elements that users can pinch and zoom, rotate, or pan.

trans-unit.source: Tap the **Multi-touch Input** button on the emulator toolbar to enable multi-point input.
trans-unit.target: Tap the **Multi-touch Input** button on the emulator toolbar to enable multi-point input.

trans-unit.source: Two touch points appear on the emulator screen around a center point.
trans-unit.target: Two touch points appear on the emulator screen around a center point.

trans-unit.source: Right-click and drag one of the touch points to position them without touching the screen.
trans-unit.target: Right-click and drag one of the touch points to position them without touching the screen.

trans-unit.source: Left-click and drag one of the touch points to simulate pinching and zooming, rotating, or panning.
trans-unit.target: Left-click and drag one of the touch points to simulate pinching and zooming, rotating, or panning.

trans-unit.source: Tap the **Single Point Input** button on the emulator toolbar to restore normal input.
trans-unit.target: Tap the **Single Point Input** button on the emulator toolbar to restore normal input.

trans-unit.target: The following screenshot shows multi-touch input.

trans-unit.target: The small left image shows the **Multi-touch Input** button on the emulator toolbar.

trans-unit.source: The middle image shows the emulator screen after tapping the **Multi-touch Input** button to display the touch points.
trans-unit.target: The middle image shows the emulator screen after tapping the **Multi-touch Input** button to display the touch points.

trans-unit.target: The right image shows the emulator screen after dragging the touch points to zoom the image.

trans-unit.source: Multi-point input option on the Emulator toolbar
trans-unit.target: Multi-point input option on the Emulator toolbar

trans-unit.source: Accelerometer
trans-unit.target: Accelerometer

trans-unit.source: Test apps that track the movement of the phone by using the **Accelerometer** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.
trans-unit.target: Test apps that track the movement of the phone by using the **Accelerometer** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.

trans-unit.source: You can test the accelerometer sensor with live input or pre-recorded input.
trans-unit.target: You can test the accelerometer sensor with live input or pre-recorded input.

trans-unit.source: The only type of recorded data that’s available simulates shaking the phone.
trans-unit.target: The only type of recorded data that’s available simulates shaking the phone.

trans-unit.source: You can’t record or save your own simulations for the accelerometer.
trans-unit.target: You can’t record or save your own simulations for the accelerometer.

trans-unit.source: Select the desired starting orientation in the **Orientation** drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: Select the desired starting orientation in the **Orientation** drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: Select the type of input.
trans-unit.target: Select the type of input.

trans-unit.source: To run the simulation with live input
trans-unit.target: To run the simulation with live input

trans-unit.source: In the middle of the accelerometer simulator, drag the colored dot to simulate movement of the device in a 3D plane.
trans-unit.target: In the middle of the accelerometer simulator, drag the colored dot to simulate movement of the device in a 3D plane.

trans-unit.source: Moving the dot on the horizontal access rotates the simulator from side to side.
trans-unit.target: Moving the dot on the horizontal access rotates the simulator from side to side.

trans-unit.source: Moving the dot on the vertical access rotates the simulator back and forth, rotating around the x-axis.
trans-unit.target: Moving the dot on the vertical access rotates the simulator back and forth, rotating around the x-axis.

trans-unit.source: As you drag the dot, the X, Y, and Z coordinates update based on the rotation calculations.
trans-unit.target: As you drag the dot, the X, Y, and Z coordinates update based on the rotation calculations.

trans-unit.source: You cannot move the dot outside the bounding circle in the touch pad area.
trans-unit.target: You cannot move the dot outside the bounding circle in the touch pad area.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, click **Reset** to restore the starting orientation.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, click **Reset** to restore the starting orientation.

trans-unit.source: To run the simulation with recorded input
trans-unit.target: To run the simulation with recorded input

trans-unit.source: In the **Recorded Data** section, click the **Play** button to start playback of the simulated data.
trans-unit.target: In the **Recorded Data** section, click the **Play** button to start playback of the simulated data.

trans-unit.source: The only option available in the **Recorded Data** list is shake.
trans-unit.target: The only option available in the **Recorded Data** list is shake.

trans-unit.source: The simulator does not move on the screen when it plays back the data.
trans-unit.target: The simulator does not move on the screen when it plays back the data.

trans-unit.source: Accelerometer page in Additional Tools for the Emulator
trans-unit.target: Accelerometer page in Additional Tools for the Emulator

trans-unit.source: Location and driving
trans-unit.target: Location and driving

trans-unit.source: Test apps that use navigation or geofencing by using the **Location** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.
trans-unit.target: Test apps that use navigation or geofencing by using the **Location** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.

trans-unit.source: This feature is useful for simulating driving, biking, or walking in conditions similar to the real world.
trans-unit.target: This feature is useful for simulating driving, biking, or walking in conditions similar to the real world.

trans-unit.source: You can test your app while you simulate moving from one location to another at different speeds and with different accuracy profiles.
trans-unit.target: You can test your app while you simulate moving from one location to another at different speeds and with different accuracy profiles.

trans-unit.source: The location simulator can help you to identify changes in your usage of the location APIs usage that improve the user experience.
trans-unit.target: The location simulator can help you to identify changes in your usage of the location APIs usage that improve the user experience.

trans-unit.source: For example, the tool can help you identify that you have to tune geofence parameters, such as size or dwell time, to detect the geofences successfully in different scenarios.
trans-unit.target: For example, the tool can help you identify that you have to tune geofence parameters, such as size or dwell time, to detect the geofences successfully in different scenarios.

trans-unit.source: The **Location** tab supports three modes.
trans-unit.target: The **Location** tab supports three modes.

trans-unit.source: In all modes, when the emulator receives a new position, that position is available to trigger the [**PositionChanged**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225540) event or to respond to a [**GetGeopositionAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh973536) call in your location-aware app.
trans-unit.target: In all modes, when the emulator receives a new position, that position is available to trigger the [**PositionChanged**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225540) event or to respond to a [**GetGeopositionAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh973536) call in your location-aware app.

trans-unit.source: In **Pin** mode, you place pushpins on the map.
trans-unit.target: In **Pin** mode, you place pushpins on the map.

trans-unit.source: When you click **Play all points**, the location simulator sends the location of each pin to the emulator one after another, at the interval specified in the **Seconds per pin** text box.
trans-unit.target: When you click **Play all points**, the location simulator sends the location of each pin to the emulator one after another, at the interval specified in the **Seconds per pin** text box.

trans-unit.source: In **Live** mode, you place pushpins on the map.
trans-unit.target: In **Live** mode, you place pushpins on the map.

trans-unit.source: The location simulator sends the location of each pin to the emulator immediately as you place them on the map.
trans-unit.target: The location simulator sends the location of each pin to the emulator immediately as you place them on the map.

trans-unit.source: In **Route** mode, you place pushpins on the map to indicate waypoints, and the location simulator automatically calculates a route.
trans-unit.target: In **Route** mode, you place pushpins on the map to indicate waypoints, and the location simulator automatically calculates a route.

trans-unit.source: The route includes invisible pins at one-second intervals along the route.
trans-unit.target: The route includes invisible pins at one-second intervals along the route.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have select the **Walking** speed profile, which assumes a speed of 5 kilometers per hour, then invisible pins are generated at intervals of 1.39 meters.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have select the **Walking** speed profile, which assumes a speed of 5 kilometers per hour, then invisible pins are generated at intervals of 1.39 meters.

trans-unit.source: When you click **Play all points**, the location simulator sends the location of each pin to the emulator one after another, at the interval determined by the speed profile selected in the drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: When you click **Play all points**, the location simulator sends the location of each pin to the emulator one after another, at the interval determined by the speed profile selected in the drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: In all modes of the location simulator, you can do the following things.
trans-unit.target: In all modes of the location simulator, you can do the following things.

trans-unit.source: You can search for a location by using the **Search** box.
trans-unit.target: You can search for a location by using the **Search** box.

trans-unit.source: You can **Zoom in** and **Zoom out** on the map.
trans-unit.target: You can **Zoom in** and **Zoom out** on the map.

trans-unit.source: You can save the current set of data points to an XML file, and reload the file later to reuse the same data points.
trans-unit.target: You can save the current set of data points to an XML file, and reload the file later to reuse the same data points.

trans-unit.source: You can **Toggle pushpin mode on or off** and **Clear all points**.
trans-unit.target: You can **Toggle pushpin mode on or off** and **Clear all points**.

trans-unit.source: In Pin and Route mode, you can also do the following things.
trans-unit.target: In Pin and Route mode, you can also do the following things.

trans-unit.source: Save a route you created for later use.
trans-unit.target: Save a route you created for later use.

trans-unit.source: Load a route previously created.
trans-unit.target: Load a route previously created.

trans-unit.source: You can even load route files created in previous versions of the tool.
trans-unit.target: You can even load route files created in previous versions of the tool.

trans-unit.source: Modify a route by deleting pushpins (in Pin mode) or waypoints (in Route mode).
trans-unit.target: Modify a route by deleting pushpins (in Pin mode) or waypoints (in Route mode).

trans-unit.source: Accuracy profiles
trans-unit.target: Accuracy profiles

trans-unit.source: In all modes of the location simulator, you can select one of the following accuracy profiles in the **Accuracy profile** drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: In all modes of the location simulator, you can select one of the following accuracy profiles in the **Accuracy profile** drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: Profile
trans-unit.target: Profile

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Pinpoint
trans-unit.target: Pinpoint

trans-unit.source: Assumes perfectly accurate location readings.
trans-unit.target: Assumes perfectly accurate location readings.

trans-unit.source: This setting is not realistic, but it's useful for testing the logic of your app.
trans-unit.target: This setting is not realistic, but it's useful for testing the logic of your app.

trans-unit.source: Urban
trans-unit.target: Urban

trans-unit.source: Assumes that buildings are restricting the number of satellites in view, but there is often a high density of cell towers and Wi-Fi access points that can be used for positioning.
trans-unit.target: Assumes that buildings are restricting the number of satellites in view, but there is often a high density of cell towers and Wi-Fi access points that can be used for positioning.

trans-unit.source: Suburban
trans-unit.target: Suburban

trans-unit.source: Assumes that satellite positioning is relatively good and there is good density of cell towers, but the density of Wi-Fi access points is not high.
trans-unit.target: Assumes that satellite positioning is relatively good and there is good density of cell towers, but the density of Wi-Fi access points is not high.

trans-unit.source: Rural
trans-unit.target: Rural

trans-unit.source: Assumes that satellite positioning is good, but there is low density of cell towers and almost no Wi-Fi access points that can be used for positioning.
trans-unit.target: Assumes that satellite positioning is good, but there is low density of cell towers and almost no Wi-Fi access points that can be used for positioning.

trans-unit.source: Speed profiles
trans-unit.target: Speed profiles

trans-unit.source: In **Route** mode, you can select one of the following speed profiles in the drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: In **Route** mode, you can select one of the following speed profiles in the drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: Profile
trans-unit.target: Profile

trans-unit.source: Speed per hour
trans-unit.target: Speed per hour

trans-unit.source: Speed per second
trans-unit.target: Speed per second

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Speed Limit
trans-unit.target: Speed Limit

trans-unit.source: Speed limit of the route
trans-unit.target: Speed limit of the route

trans-unit.source: Not applicable
trans-unit.target: Not applicable

trans-unit.source: Traverse the route at the posted speed limit.
trans-unit.target: Traverse the route at the posted speed limit.

trans-unit.source: Walking
trans-unit.target: Walking

trans-unit.source: 5 km/h
trans-unit.target: 5 km/h

trans-unit.source: Traverse the route at a natural walking pace of 5 km/h.
trans-unit.target: Traverse the route at a natural walking pace of 5 km/h.

trans-unit.source: Biking
trans-unit.target: Biking

trans-unit.source: 25 km/h
trans-unit.target: 25 km/h

trans-unit.source: Traverse the route at a natural biking pace of 25 km/h.
trans-unit.target: Traverse the route at a natural biking pace of 25 km/h.

trans-unit.source: Fast
trans-unit.target: Fast

trans-unit.source: Traverse the route faster than the posted speed limit.
trans-unit.target: Traverse the route faster than the posted speed limit.

trans-unit.source: Route mode
trans-unit.target: Route mode

trans-unit.source: Route mode has the following features and limitations.
trans-unit.target: Route mode has the following features and limitations.

trans-unit.source: Route mode requires an Internet connection.
trans-unit.target: Route mode requires an Internet connection.

trans-unit.source: When the Urban, Suburban, or Rural accuracy profile is selected, the location simulator calculates a simulated satellite-based position, a simulated Wi-Fi position, and a simulated cellular position for each pin.
trans-unit.target: When the Urban, Suburban, or Rural accuracy profile is selected, the location simulator calculates a simulated satellite-based position, a simulated Wi-Fi position, and a simulated cellular position for each pin.

trans-unit.source: Your app receives only one of these positions.
trans-unit.target: Your app receives only one of these positions.

trans-unit.source: The three sets of coordinates for the current location are displayed in different colors on the map and in the **Current location** list.
trans-unit.target: The three sets of coordinates for the current location are displayed in different colors on the map and in the **Current location** list.

trans-unit.source: The accuracy of the pins along route the route is not uniform.
trans-unit.target: The accuracy of the pins along route the route is not uniform.

trans-unit.source: Some of the pins use satellite accuracy, some use Wi-Fi accuracy, and some use cellular accuracy.
trans-unit.target: Some of the pins use satellite accuracy, some use Wi-Fi accuracy, and some use cellular accuracy.

trans-unit.source: You cannot select more than 20 waypoints for the route.
trans-unit.target: You cannot select more than 20 waypoints for the route.

trans-unit.source: Positions for the visible and invisible pins on the map are generated only once when you select a new accuracy profile.
trans-unit.target: Positions for the visible and invisible pins on the map are generated only once when you select a new accuracy profile.

trans-unit.source: When you play the route more than once with the same accuracy profile during the same emulator session, the previously generated positions are reused.
trans-unit.target: When you play the route more than once with the same accuracy profile during the same emulator session, the previously generated positions are reused.

trans-unit.target: The following screenshot shows Route mode.

trans-unit.target: The orange line indicates the route.

trans-unit.source: The blue dot indicates the accurate location of the car determined by satellite-based positioning.
trans-unit.target: The blue dot indicates the accurate location of the car determined by satellite-based positioning.

trans-unit.source: The red and green dots indicate less accurate locations calculated by using Wi-Fi and cellular positioning and the Suburban accuracy profile.
trans-unit.target: The red and green dots indicate less accurate locations calculated by using Wi-Fi and cellular positioning and the Suburban accuracy profile.

trans-unit.source: The three calculated locations are also displayed in the **Current location** list.

trans-unit.target: Location page in Additional Tools for the Emulator

trans-unit.source: More info about the location simulator
trans-unit.target: More info about the location simulator

trans-unit.source: You can request a position with the accuracy set to Default.
trans-unit.target: You can request a position with the accuracy set to Default.

trans-unit.source: A limitation that existed in the Windows Phone 8 version of the location simulator, and required you to request a position with the accuracy set to High, has been fixed.
trans-unit.target: A limitation that existed in the Windows Phone 8 version of the location simulator, and required you to request a position with the accuracy set to High, has been fixed.

trans-unit.source: When you test geofencing in the emulator, create a simulation that gives the geofencing engine a “warm-up” period to learn and adjust to the movement patterns.
trans-unit.target: When you test geofencing in the emulator, create a simulation that gives the geofencing engine a “warm-up” period to learn and adjust to the movement patterns.

trans-unit.source: The only position properties that are simulated are the Latitude, Longitude, Accuracy, and PositionSource.
trans-unit.target: The only position properties that are simulated are the Latitude, Longitude, Accuracy, and PositionSource.

trans-unit.source: The location simulator does not simulate other properties such as Speed, Heading, and so forth.
trans-unit.target: The location simulator does not simulate other properties such as Speed, Heading, and so forth.

trans-unit.source: Network
trans-unit.target: Network

trans-unit.source: Test your app with different network speeds and different signal strengths by using the **Network** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.
trans-unit.target: Test your app with different network speeds and different signal strengths by using the **Network** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.

trans-unit.source: This feature is useful if your app calls web services or transfers data.
trans-unit.target: This feature is useful if your app calls web services or transfers data.

trans-unit.source: The network simulation feature helps you to make sure that your app runs well in the real world.
trans-unit.target: The network simulation feature helps you to make sure that your app runs well in the real world.

trans-unit.source: The Windows Phone Emulator runs on a computer that usually has a fast WiFi or Ethernet connection.
trans-unit.target: The Windows Phone Emulator runs on a computer that usually has a fast WiFi or Ethernet connection.

trans-unit.source: Your app, however, runs on phones that are typically connected over a slower cellular connection.
trans-unit.target: Your app, however, runs on phones that are typically connected over a slower cellular connection.

trans-unit.source: Check **Enable network simulation** to test your app with different network speeds and different signal strengths.
trans-unit.target: Check **Enable network simulation** to test your app with different network speeds and different signal strengths.

trans-unit.source: In the **Network speed** dropdown list, select one of the following options:
trans-unit.target: In the **Network speed** dropdown list, select one of the following options:

trans-unit.source: No network
trans-unit.target: No network

trans-unit.source: 2G
trans-unit.target: 2G

trans-unit.source: 3G
trans-unit.target: 3G

trans-unit.source: 4G
trans-unit.target: 4G

trans-unit.source: In the **Signal strength** dropdown list, select one of the following options:
trans-unit.target: In the **Signal strength** dropdown list, select one of the following options:

trans-unit.source: Good
trans-unit.target: Good

trans-unit.source: Average
trans-unit.target: Average

trans-unit.source: Poor
trans-unit.target: Poor

trans-unit.source: Clear **Enable network simulation** to restore the default behavior, which uses the network settings of your development computer.
trans-unit.target: Clear **Enable network simulation** to restore the default behavior, which uses the network settings of your development computer.

trans-unit.source: You can also review the current network settings on the **Network** tab.
trans-unit.target: You can also review the current network settings on the **Network** tab.

trans-unit.source: Network page in Additional Tools for the Emulator
trans-unit.target: Network page in Additional Tools for the Emulator

trans-unit.source: SD card
trans-unit.target: SD card

trans-unit.source: Test your app with a simulated removable SD card by using the **SD Card** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.
trans-unit.target: Test your app with a simulated removable SD card by using the **SD Card** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.

trans-unit.source: This feature is useful if your app reads or write files.
trans-unit.target: This feature is useful if your app reads or write files.

trans-unit.source: SD Card page in Additional Tools for the Emulator
trans-unit.target: SD Card page in Additional Tools for the Emulator

trans-unit.source: The **SD Card** tab uses a folder on the development computer to simulate a removable SD card in the phone.
trans-unit.target: The **SD Card** tab uses a folder on the development computer to simulate a removable SD card in the phone.

trans-unit.source: **Select a folder**.
trans-unit.target: **Select a folder**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Browse** to pick a folder on the development computer to hold the contents of the simulated SD card.
trans-unit.target: Click **Browse** to pick a folder on the development computer to hold the contents of the simulated SD card.

trans-unit.source: **Insert the SD card**.
trans-unit.target: **Insert the SD card**.

trans-unit.source: After selecting a folder, click **Insert SD card**.
trans-unit.target: After selecting a folder, click **Insert SD card**.

trans-unit.source: When you insert the SD card, the following things happen:
trans-unit.target: When you insert the SD card, the following things happen:

trans-unit.source: If you didn't specify a folder, or the folder's not valid, an error occurs.
trans-unit.target: If you didn't specify a folder, or the folder's not valid, an error occurs.

trans-unit.source: The files in the specified folder on the development computer are copied to the root folder of the simulated SD card on the emulator.
trans-unit.target: The files in the specified folder on the development computer are copied to the root folder of the simulated SD card on the emulator.

trans-unit.source: A progress bar indicates the progress of the sync operation.
trans-unit.target: A progress bar indicates the progress of the sync operation.

trans-unit.source: The **Insert the SD card** button changes to **Eject SD card**.
trans-unit.target: The **Insert the SD card** button changes to **Eject SD card**.

trans-unit.source: If you click **Eject SD card** while the sync operation is in progress, the operation is canceled.
trans-unit.target: If you click **Eject SD card** while the sync operation is in progress, the operation is canceled.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, select or clear **Sync updated files back to the local folder when I eject the SD card**.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, select or clear **Sync updated files back to the local folder when I eject the SD card**.

trans-unit.source: This option is enabled by default.
trans-unit.target: This option is enabled by default.

trans-unit.source: When this option is enabled, files are synced from the emulator back to the folder on the development computer when you eject the SD card.
trans-unit.target: When this option is enabled, files are synced from the emulator back to the folder on the development computer when you eject the SD card.

trans-unit.source: **Eject the SD card**.
trans-unit.target: **Eject the SD card**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Eject SD card**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Eject SD card**.

trans-unit.source: When you eject the SD card, the following things happen:
trans-unit.target: When you eject the SD card, the following things happen:

trans-unit.source: if you have selected **Sync updated files back to the local folder when I eject the SD card**, the following things happen:
trans-unit.target: if you have selected **Sync updated files back to the local folder when I eject the SD card**, the following things happen:

trans-unit.source: The files on the simulated SD card on the emulator are copied to the specified folder on the development computer.
trans-unit.target: The files on the simulated SD card on the emulator are copied to the specified folder on the development computer.

trans-unit.source: A progress bar indicates the progress of the sync operation.
trans-unit.target: A progress bar indicates the progress of the sync operation.

trans-unit.source: The **Eject SD card** button changes to **Cancel sync**.
trans-unit.target: The **Eject SD card** button changes to **Cancel sync**.

trans-unit.source: If you click **Cancel sync** while the sync operation is in progress, the card is ejected and the results of the sync operation are incomplete.
trans-unit.target: If you click **Cancel sync** while the sync operation is in progress, the card is ejected and the results of the sync operation are incomplete.

trans-unit.source: The **Eject SD card** button changes back to **Insert SD card**.
trans-unit.target: The **Eject SD card** button changes back to **Insert SD card**.

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: Since an SD card used by the phone is formatted with the FAT32 file system, 32GB is the maximum size.
trans-unit.target: Since an SD card used by the phone is formatted with the FAT32 file system, 32GB is the maximum size.

trans-unit.source: The speed of reading from and writing to the simulated SD card is throttled to imitate real-world speeds.
trans-unit.target: The speed of reading from and writing to the simulated SD card is throttled to imitate real-world speeds.

trans-unit.source: Accessing an SD card is slower than accessing the computer's hard drive.
trans-unit.target: Accessing an SD card is slower than accessing the computer's hard drive.

trans-unit.source: Notifications
trans-unit.target: Notifications

trans-unit.source: Send push notifications to your app by using the **Notifications** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.
trans-unit.target: Send push notifications to your app by using the **Notifications** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.

trans-unit.source: This feature is useful if your app receives push notifications.
trans-unit.target: This feature is useful if your app receives push notifications.

trans-unit.source: You can easily test push notifications without creating the working cloud service that's required after you publish your app.
trans-unit.target: You can easily test push notifications without creating the working cloud service that's required after you publish your app.

trans-unit.source: Enable simulation.
trans-unit.target: Enable simulation.

trans-unit.source: After you select **Enabled**, all apps deployed on the emulator use the simulation engine instead of the WNS or MPN service until you disable simulation.
trans-unit.target: After you select **Enabled**, all apps deployed on the emulator use the simulation engine instead of the WNS or MPN service until you disable simulation.

trans-unit.source: Select an app to receive notifications.
trans-unit.target: Select an app to receive notifications.

trans-unit.source: The **AppId** list is automatically populated with all apps deployed to the emulator that are enabled for push notifications.
trans-unit.target: The **AppId** list is automatically populated with all apps deployed to the emulator that are enabled for push notifications.

trans-unit.source: Select an app in the drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: Select an app in the drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: If you deploy another push-enabled app after enabling simulation, click **Refresh** to add the app to the list.
trans-unit.target: If you deploy another push-enabled app after enabling simulation, click **Refresh** to add the app to the list.

trans-unit.source: Select a notification channel.
trans-unit.target: Select a notification channel.

trans-unit.source: After you select an app in the **AppId** list, the **URI** list is automatically populated with all the notification channels registered for the selected app.
trans-unit.target: After you select an app in the **AppId** list, the **URI** list is automatically populated with all the notification channels registered for the selected app.

trans-unit.source: Select a notification channel in the drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: Select a notification channel in the drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: Select a notification type.
trans-unit.target: Select a notification type.

trans-unit.source: After you select a notification channel in the **URI** list, the **Notification Type** list is automatically populated with all the types available for the notification service.
trans-unit.target: After you select a notification channel in the **URI** list, the **Notification Type** list is automatically populated with all the types available for the notification service.

trans-unit.source: Select a notification type in the drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: Select a notification type in the drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: The simulator uses the Uri format of the notification channel to determine whether the app is using WNS or MPN push notifications.
trans-unit.target: The simulator uses the Uri format of the notification channel to determine whether the app is using WNS or MPN push notifications.

trans-unit.source: Simulation supports all notification types.
trans-unit.target: Simulation supports all notification types.

trans-unit.source: The default notification type is **Tile**.
trans-unit.target: The default notification type is **Tile**.

trans-unit.source: The following WNS notification types are supported.
trans-unit.target: The following WNS notification types are supported.

trans-unit.source: Raw
trans-unit.target: Raw

trans-unit.source: Toast
trans-unit.target: Toast

trans-unit.source: When your app uses WNS notifications and you select the **Toast** notification type, the simulation tab displays the **Tag** and **Group** fields.
trans-unit.target: When your app uses WNS notifications and you select the **Toast** notification type, the simulation tab displays the **Tag** and **Group** fields.

trans-unit.source: You can select these options and enter **Tag** and **Group** values to manage toast notifications in the Notification Center.
trans-unit.target: You can select these options and enter **Tag** and **Group** values to manage toast notifications in the Notification Center.

trans-unit.source: Tile
trans-unit.target: Tile

trans-unit.source: Badge
trans-unit.target: Badge

trans-unit.source: The following MPN notification types are supported.
trans-unit.target: The following MPN notification types are supported.

trans-unit.source: Raw
trans-unit.target: Raw

trans-unit.source: Toast
trans-unit.target: Toast

trans-unit.source: Tile
trans-unit.target: Tile

trans-unit.source: Select a notification template.
trans-unit.target: Select a notification template.

trans-unit.source: After you select a notification type in the **Notification Type** list, the **Templates** list is automatically populated with all the templates available for the notification type.
trans-unit.target: After you select a notification type in the **Notification Type** list, the **Templates** list is automatically populated with all the templates available for the notification type.

trans-unit.source: Select a template in the drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: Select a template in the drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: Simulation supports all template types.
trans-unit.target: Simulation supports all template types.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, change the notification payload.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, change the notification payload.

trans-unit.source: After you select a template in the **Templates** list, the **Notification Payload** text box is automatically populated with a sample payload for the template.
trans-unit.target: After you select a template in the **Templates** list, the **Notification Payload** text box is automatically populated with a sample payload for the template.

trans-unit.source: Review the sample payload in the **Notification Payload** text box.
trans-unit.target: Review the sample payload in the **Notification Payload** text box.

trans-unit.source: You can send the sample payload without changing it.
trans-unit.target: You can send the sample payload without changing it.

trans-unit.source: You can edit the sample payload in the text box.
trans-unit.target: You can edit the sample payload in the text box.

trans-unit.source: You can click **Load** to load a payload from a text or XML file.
trans-unit.target: You can click **Load** to load a payload from a text or XML file.

trans-unit.source: You can click **Save** to save the XML text of the payload to use again later.
trans-unit.target: You can click **Save** to save the XML text of the payload to use again later.

trans-unit.source: The simulator does not validate the XML text of the payload.
trans-unit.target: The simulator does not validate the XML text of the payload.

trans-unit.source: Send the push notification.
trans-unit.target: Send the push notification.

trans-unit.source: Click **Send** to deliver the push notification to the selected app.
trans-unit.target: Click **Send** to deliver the push notification to the selected app.

trans-unit.source: The screen displays a message to indicate success or failure.
trans-unit.target: The screen displays a message to indicate success or failure.

trans-unit.source: Notifications page in Additional Tools for the Emulator
trans-unit.target: Notifications page in Additional Tools for the Emulator

trans-unit.source: Sensors
trans-unit.target: Sensors

trans-unit.source: Test how your app works on low-cost phones that don't have all the optional sensors or camera features by using the **Sensors** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.
trans-unit.target: Test how your app works on low-cost phones that don't have all the optional sensors or camera features by using the **Sensors** tab of the emulator's **Additional Tools**.

trans-unit.source: This feature is useful if your app uses the camera or some of the phone's sensors, and you want your app to reach the largest possible market.
trans-unit.target: This feature is useful if your app uses the camera or some of the phone's sensors, and you want your app to reach the largest possible market.

trans-unit.source: By default, all sensors are enabled in the **Optional sensors** list.
trans-unit.target: By default, all sensors are enabled in the **Optional sensors** list.

trans-unit.source: Select or clear individual check boxes to enable or disable individual sensors.
trans-unit.target: Select or clear individual check boxes to enable or disable individual sensors.

trans-unit.source: After you change your selections, click **Apply**.
trans-unit.target: After you change your selections, click **Apply**.

trans-unit.source: Then you have to restart the emulator.
trans-unit.target: Then you have to restart the emulator.

trans-unit.source: If you make changes, and then you switch tabs or close the **Additional Tools** window without clicking **Apply**, your changes are discarded.
trans-unit.target: If you make changes, and then you switch tabs or close the **Additional Tools** window without clicking **Apply**, your changes are discarded.

trans-unit.source: Your settings are persisted between for the emulator session until you change them or reset them.
trans-unit.target: Your settings are persisted between for the emulator session until you change them or reset them.

trans-unit.source: If you capture a checkpoint, the settings are saved with the checkpoint.
trans-unit.target: If you capture a checkpoint, the settings are saved with the checkpoint.

trans-unit.source: The settings are persisted only for the specific emulator that you're using - for example, **Emulator 8.1 WVGA 4" 512MB**.
trans-unit.target: The settings are persisted only for the specific emulator that you're using - for example, **Emulator 8.1 WVGA 4" 512MB**.
